qas.question: In what environment are bacteria being cultivated in labs?
Which media is preffered to grow larger volumes of bacteria?
Which environment is better to isolate a single example of bacteria strain?
What can help to indentify specific bacteria?

context: In the laboratory, bacteria are usually grown using <a0_0>solid or liquid media<a0_0/>. Solid growth media, such as <a1_0><a3_0>agar plates<a3_0/><a1_0/>, are used to isolate pure cultures of a bacterial strain. However, <a2_0>liquid growth media<a2_0/> are used when measurement of growth or large volumes of cells are required. Growth in stirred liquid media occurs as an even cell suspension, making the cultures easy to divide and transfer, although isolating single bacteria from liquid media is difficult. <a4_0>The use of selective media<a4_0/> (media with specific nutrients added or deficient, or with antibiotics added) can help identify specific organisms.
